The algebraic sum of currents at any node equals zero:

Σ I_node = 0

Or: Currents in = Currents out

Based on: Conservation of charge

The algebraic sum of voltages around any closed loop equals zero:

Σ V_loop = 0

Or: Voltage rises = Voltage drops

Based on: Conservation of energy

A point where two or more circuit elements connect.

Key insight: All points connected by ideal wire are the SAME node (no voltage difference across ideal wire).

cards.front: What is a Loop vs a Mesh?
cards.back:
Loop: Any closed path through a circuit

Mesh: A loop that contains no other loops inside it (the 'smallest' loops in a planar circuit)

For a circuit with N nodes:

Independent KCL equations = N - 1

(The Nth equation is automatically satisfied if the others are)

For a circuit with B branches and N nodes:

Independent KVL equations = B - N + 1

(This equals the number of meshes in a planar circuit)

Standard convention:
• Current entering node: POSITIVE
• Current leaving node: NEGATIVE

Then: Σ I = 0

(Or use: Σ I_in = Σ I_out)

Standard convention (tracing clockwise):
• Voltage rise (− to +): POSITIVE
• Voltage drop (+ to −): NEGATIVE

Then: Σ V = 0

For any circuit satisfying KCL and KVL:

Σ v_k · i_k = 0

Meaning: Total power delivered = Total power absorbed

Useful for checking solutions!

For two resistors R₁ and R₂ in parallel with total current I:

I₁ = I × R₂/(R₁ + R₂)

I₂ = I × R₁/(R₁ + R₂)

Current splits inversely proportional to resistance.
